headline.main: States Offer Plan To Settle Tobacco Suits

docs.abstract: Negotiators for state attorneys general and anti-smoking groups present revised proposal to cigarette makers under which companies would make annual payments indefinitely to resolve various legal and regulatory issues involving smoking (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Negotiators for state attorneys general and anti-smoking groups presented a revised proposal to cigarette makers last night under which the companies would make annual payments indefinitely to resolve various legal and regulatory issues involving smoking, people close to the talks said. Under the plan, the industry would first make payments of about $10 billion a year, which would increase to some $15 billion a year over a period of about five years, the sources said. An earlier proposal involved a closed-end settlement in which the industry would have paid $300 billion over 25 years.

headline.main: Beleaguered Tobacco Foe Holds Key to Talks

docs.abstract: National Center for Tobacco-Free Kids aide Matthew Myers, tobacco industry foe, is key figure in secret settlement talks with tobacco industry; is only original negotiator without financial stake in deal and is likely to influence Clinton Administration stand on any accord; public health advocates are bitterly divided over whether he should be part of talks; he discusses his concerns about taking part in talks, interview; photo (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: Matthew Myers slumped in his chair, looking like a man on the way to the guillotine. All morning long, fellow tobacco opponents, people with whom he had battled the industry for more than 15 years, had been offering terse smiles and sympathetic pats on the back. ''I don't like that,'' he complained as a colleague gently touched his shoulder. ''This is not a funeral.''
